head.title: Ideas & Trends; Happiness Is A Tube of Macaroni

hedline.hl1: Ideas & Trends; Happiness Is A Tube of Macaroni

abstract.p: Eric Asimov appraises three new hyperconvenience foods: IncrEdibles, which pack messy foods into tubes with stick on end, McSalad Shaker, served in soft-drink cup, and Chili & Scoops; photos (M)

block.p: IN eating, as in life, style counts. So I will say this straight out: I'm not the sort of guy who willingly eats meals-on-a-stick.

Apparently not everyone shares my dim view. Breakaway Foods recently introduced IncrEdibles, tubular containers of such unlikely dishes as scrambled eggs and macaroni with cheese, served on a stick and meant to be eaten on the run. IncrEdibles are just one of several new foods that, to hear the marketers tell it, are exactly what time-starved consumers are yearning for.
IN eating, as in life, style counts. So I will say this straight out: I'm not the sort of guy who willingly eats meals-on-a-stick.

Apparently not everyone shares my dim view. Breakaway Foods recently introduced IncrEdibles, tubular containers of such unlikely dishes as scrambled eggs and macaroni with cheese, served on a stick and meant to be eaten on the run. IncrEdibles are just one of several new foods that, to hear the marketers tell it, are exactly what time-starved consumers are yearning for.

Despite my skepticism, I found that IncrEdibles' scrambled eggs-on-a-stick wasn't bad at all, certainly better than the typically leathery coffee shop scrambled eggs. But as I looked at the slender cylinder, which you microwave and then hold like a Popsicle as you push the food up through the top, I couldn't help wondering, what's the point?

Of course, the on-the-stick concept has clear antecedents. Anybody who's ever been to a tractor pull is intimately familiar with the corn dog, a breaded frankfurter on a stick, which has been life's blood at county fairs for more than half a century.

Another entry in the ''hyperconvenience'' market, Frito-Lay's Chili & Scoops, is likewise a repackaging of an old idea, the Frito pie. In fact, Chili & Scoops, which pairs in one package a bag of scoop-shaped corn chips and a container of microwaveable chili, is a step backward in convenience from the Frito pie, in which you open a bag of Fritos and pour the chili directly into the bag and over the chips. As truck drivers know, one container beats two anytime.

Breakaway Foods asserts that IncrEdibles is the logical next step in a progression that includes Wonder Bread, airline food and TV dinners. I agree with them completely, though I will leave you to decide whether this is a good thing.
Impressions of three hyperconvenience foods follow, in order of preference.
